reviewText: Their Mom has died and Dad sweeps them away to the far north.  The daughter thrives and the son whines, at least that's the way it begins.  Dad is now a bush pilot and when his plane goes down in a storm and can't be located by the local rescue unit, brother and sister set out to try and find him.  The cast is very good, especially the kids.  Remember "Dani" from Hocus Pocus and "Oz" from Masterminds?  This is one movie you will watch several time without getting tired of it.

reviewText: In an awesome Alaska setting, two children, one pre-teen, one teen, take off on an adventure-packed trek to rescue their father, a downed pilot.  On the way they encounter poachers, setting free a polar bear cub who becomes their beacon.  Improbable?  Undoubtedly.  One might even say impossible.  Nonetheless, this was a delightful film which I shared with my grandchildren, and enjoyed every bit as much as they did.

reviewText: This is just entertainment, but I find it interesting some of the points made by the critics. It is true that typically you wouldn't find a polar bear in the mountains. But did you know, EXPERTS ON THE MATTER, have recently found that polar bears have mated with grizzlies in the wild and furthermore people have been known to transport them to other areas as well. And last time I heard grizzlies don't go where the polar bears are. Well one of them is travelling where they SUPPOSEDLY DON'T GO. So before you get stuffed shirt on how it isn't feasible, don't kid yourself, anything is possible. The movie will appeal to young children the most, some teens, and those adults that enjoy Disney style action movies.

This is a very underrated film. The young and old will have a good time with this. DVD is also in Widescreen and it has Pan & Scan format. Super 35. Grade:B.

reviewText: This isn't exactly a great movie.  I've seen much better, but thankfully, I've also seen worse.  The scenery is nice enough (filmed in British Columbia, where I happen to live), but that's about all I liked.  The plot  was much too far-fetched, what two kids would run around on a mountaineous  wilderness, even for their father?  I also got sick of the polar bear, his  sweetness was just too much.  Otherwise, the movie was all right.  Not  great, but not bad either.

reviewText: An incredible adventure with all the rugged beauty of Alaska! Definitely a 'follow your heart' movie . . . one doesn't have to accept the reality of life but focus on the message, lessons learned and the absolutely fantastic scenery.The story line: brother and sister are 'determined' to find their father and in doing so, find themselves. Loss of wife/mother means a move from the Chicago city life of a 747 pilot and his teenage children. The siblings are bound together in a journey of the heart. Their father is now a 'bush pilot' in a remote area of Alaska and encounters a storm with  weather conditions that cause his plane to crash on mountain crags.  Intertwined is another story of an orphaned polar bear cub. Mother bear is killed by poachers and the cub is captured for 'live' sale on the foreign market. The young adventures stumble on the poachers' camp and release  'Cubby.' In turn 'Cubby' follows them and then becomes their guide.This movie offers a panorama of wilderness scenes and a venture that follows the heart. Reality or realistic? Absolutely not! Will it bring smiles and a heartwarming story? Yes!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a good movie, even for kids, although I don't appreciate the violation of the Third Commandment.  Its plot would seem impossible had I not been recently told by a friend of mine of two people in Oregon that used to have pet bears back in the days of real woodsmanship (he knew them).  I don't want to spoil it for you, so you might want to skip the rest.A teenage brother and his teenage sister are living with their recently widowed father, an airline pilot recently turned bush pilot, in southeast or southcentral Alaska.  The sister loves the Alaskan life, and likes a local "native" boy.  The brother would rather be back in Chicago watching professional baseball.  Then dad attempts to fly some Amoxicillin on his four-seater to someone in need as a storm is approaching.  He crashes, alive but with a broken leg.The siblings, alone at home and through most of the film not always getting along with each other, lose radio contact with him, and set out on a search in which they encounter an orphaned polar bear cub caged for illegal transport by a pair of poachers.  The plot thickens, but I don't want to ruin it for you.Ever see Heidi?  I think this is where the idea of the ending came from.  It's a fun movie, showing the beauty of south central Alaska and the dangers posed by both the wilderness and those who abuse its resources.  But I have problems with polar bears in that part of Alaska, for I don't think that they live there (I could be wrong).

reviewText: This movie tells the story of two young people, Jessie and Sean, who have moved to Alaska with their father after their mother's death.  Jessie is making the best of the move, but Sean is very unhappy that he has been uprooted from his home in Chicago.  When their father's plane crashes during what was to have been a routine flight, Jessie and Sean decide to rescue him.  What follows is totally unbelievable, but there is some exciting action during the rescue and the scenery is spectacular.  Mostly designed as a children's movie, the scenery is probably the best part for adults.
summary: Predictable and unbelievable at the same time

reviewText: Very slow and not nearly as intense as this would play out in reality. Cinematography is incredible. Thora Birch, a proven and capable actor, seems to struggle trying to carry the other actors. Charlton Heston is magnificent. He's lost absolutely none of his regal and virile presence. His 'big star, big screen' countenance was equaled only by the majesty of the setting and not by the role. Poorly written, maudlin and predictable, but worth seeing Charlton Heston and Alaska.
Title: N/A

reviewText: What a pleasant surprise to find this movie.The movie follows 2 Chicago raised kids, now living in Alaska with their dad after the death of their mom. The daughter embraces the new adventures and activities of the area; kayaking with a native friend, learning the area and tracking her dad's flights on ham radio - while the son fights the change wanting nothing more than to return to Chicago.The dad pilots an urgent flight to deliver medical supplies and is caught in a storm and crashes in the mountains.  After some search attempts to find him prove fruitless, the 2 kids decide to take matters into their own hands and set out to find and rescue their dad themselves.  They stop at a poachers encampment and find the skin of a mamma polar bear and a caged baby polar bear. They let the bear loose and go on their way, but the bear seems to see them as it's new parents and tracks them.  Meanwhile the poachers return to camp to find their cub missing and set off to recapture it.  So, now the kids are dealing with perilous wilderness, a bear cub, and poachers (who are not on the kids side).This is a wonderful adventure filled with peril and BEAUTIFUL scenery. Yeah...some of it is a bit far fetched, but try not to think about it and just go along for the ride.  It's a decent film.  Enjoy! :-)
Title: N/A

reviewText: Hard to figure the negative comments about this film. It is geared to an elementary school audience who will find it very entertaining. But it is also good family viewing because the scenery is terrific and the polar bear cub is very cute. Since there was never a conspiracy to keep the demographic identity of the target audience a national secret, those complaining about its lack of sophistication were just too lazy to check it out before actually viewing it. The film delivers exactly what it promises so there is no real basis for that kind of criticism.The editing is first class; especially on the canoe down the rapids sequence where the second unit stuff is perfectly cut into tight shots of the two stars. Thora Birch turns in another excellent performance and Vincent Kartheiser shows that even before "Angel" he modeled his acting on William Shatner (this is not a complement).There are a number of plot holes but nothing that really matters. One interesting thing is the scene where the bear cub helps in the rescue effort by pulling the rope with his teeth. Seldom can you point to a "single" stupid detail that drastically dumbs down a film but that is the case here. Lose that one moronic shot and the film gains about 20 IQ points and could add a couple years to its target audience.Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child.
summary: What part of: "This is a Children's Film" don't you understand?

reviewText: ALASKA is a great "FAMILY MOVIE". And it may sound a little "lame" and "unrealistic" to some people but it's a movie that most kids will enjoy...even adults. ALASKA is about a brother and a sister who's family moved to a tiny island in Alaska after their mother died. Their father becomes a delivery pilot and goes off one day to deliver toliet paper, not knowing that there's a huge storm coming up (this is, of course, after the son and father just had a huge fight and after the son told the father he wished his father had died instead of his mother). When his jet plane crashes into the Alaskan wildnerness -  actually into a huge mountain - and the kids realize that their father is missing. Even though the police say he's dead the next day because they can't find him, the son insists that his father is still alive and goes out to search for him...followed by his sister, who at first doesn't agree with his searching but goes after him anyway, claiming that she's the only one who knows how to survive out there. Anyway, while out searching, the two kids meet two poochers traveling alone. They find the poochers' camp site and find the polar bear cub, who's mother had been killed by the poochers. After they set the cub free, the baby cub starts following them as they go on in search for their father.ALASKA is a really great film, although like in many kids' movies, it's pretty predictable. Still, the casting is great with excellent acting. Also, the setting of the film looks very realistic...the scenary for the movie is amazing! (I don't know if they actually filmed the movie in Alaska...but it sure does look that way!) So even if you don't really care much for seeing this movie, you should at least check out the scenary of the movie because the scenary is incredible! Once again, a great film for all ages.
summary: Duh...this is a "Family Film", what more could you expect?

reviewText: Both the river stunts and the nature photography in this picture are excellent, but the plot is mostly unbelievable.A man exposed in a small airplane in sub-freezing temperature for a week may live two days, maybe if he has really warm clothes.Not a week while his kids hike in...And the bear cub attaching itself to the teenagers: that doesn't seem likely either.Most of the plot is a Dizzy type made for kids movie.The most believable thing in the movie is the Carlton Heston villain of a helicopter poacher!
summary: Alaska is a really dangerous place to fly an airplane

reviewText: A movie cannot get any further from reality and for that reason alone may not be suitable for children. If kids watch they have to understand that it is completely HAPPY HORSE MANURE....but it is uplifting to imagine for just a moment that the impossible is possible...  I live in the Rockies so I know a fair amount about bears, severe weather, and hypothermia. Dad would have been dead long before the kids got there...the kids would never have made it there...the bad poachers would have killed the kids...the polar bear cub would never have cozied up to the kids...and you have a better chance of hitting the lottery than that cub had of having the polar bear sow adopt him.It doesn't matter. It is a feel good movie and made me feel good.I did need to take a shower to wash off all of that happy horse manure....:-)

reviewText: SPOILER ALERT: This review contains detailed descriptions of the plot of this movie.Remember the terribly sad scene at the beginning of Bambi, where little Bambi's mom gets killed by a hunter? Remember how sad that scene makes little kids? Well, the scene at the beginning of this movie, where little polar bear "Cubby" loses his mom, is even MORE traumatic than the Bambi scene. The poachers are cruel, one of them taunting the sad baby polar bear with the severed head of his mother. It is really awful. I kept finding myself crying at random throughout the movie, just thinking about it -- and I am an adult! Then later is another scene where little Cubby gets shot. It turns out to be just a tranquilizer dart, but at first it seems as though he might have been killed. I don't think this movie is appropriate for younger viewers, even though that's the only demographic I think would appreciate it.It's also misleading. The harshness of that terrain, the youth and inexperience of the main characters, and the various troubles that befall them (head injury, lost kayak, etc.) would have caused far more risky and life-threatening situations in real life than were depicted in this movie. Children should absolutely be spending time learning the skills to survive in the wild (i.e., learning how to live on planet Earth), but this movie fails to teach anything meaningful about primitive skills. For example, when they need to build a fire to keep from freezing, one of them even makes a joke of the idea of "rubbing two sticks together." Children can and do learn to make fire from such materials as wood, grass, and rocks. Many of the most important skills are not difficult, they just take practice. If these two children had known how to make a bow drill fire and a debris hut, their success would not seem so contrived and like Hollywood nonsense. You can see videos of children doing these things easily enough on youtube, for example on the channel 'primitiveskills' and many others. For this movie to make light of such skills and then provide the kids with a zippo lighter was nothing but deus ex machina and an insult to those who do take the time to learn and teach to children these skills.

reviewText: The only reason for giving this turkey a 2 is Charlton Heston's presence. The script is completely implausible. If you believe that a wild polar bear cub has the strength and awareness to tug on a rope supporting a grown man and a hefty teenager to keep them from falling off a cliff, you might get some enjoyment out of this film. This would stretch the imagination of the most ardent animal lover. How about a teenager and a pre-teen wondering off into the Alaskan wilderness for days with marshmallow pies and minimal survival gear ? Throughout the film the scenery is beautiful, but it is completely void of the tendency for Alaskan weather to turn foul quickly. If you enjoy pure fantasy, you might enjoy this film.
Title: N/A

reviewText: ALASKA is a good ol', straight forward, adventure film reminiscent of the type of programming shown on THE WONDERFUL WORLD OF DISNEY tv anthology show back in the 60's and 70's. Good,solid, family entertainment with great location shots of the Alaskan wilderness. While delivering supplies, bush pilot Jake Barnes' (Dirk Benedict) plane is downed during a snow storm. Then, his son and daughter, Sean and Jessie, (Vincent Kartheiser and Thora Birch) take it upon themselves to find him and trek through the remote Alaskan wilderness and rivers.  They run into two poachers (Perry and Ben) and let loose an illegally captive baby polar bear. The cub immediately 'adopts' the two kids as his new friends and follows them on their trek. Not too complicated, but entertaining nontheless with some narrow escapes and decent action sequences along with some light emotional scenes.  Good to see actor Dirk Benedict (A-TEAM, BATTLESTAR GALACTICA) doing some work along with veteran Charlton Heston in an uncharacteristic villian role as one of the poachers. He's probably in the film because his son Fraser C. Heston directed.
Title: N/A
